rev.comment: This media use does not comply with [[WP:NFCC]] #10c and MUST be removed until it does. Thank you.
rev.diff:
Line 99: Line 99:
==In popular culture==
==In popular culture==
â
[[Image:Sudden-impact-10.jpg|left|thumbnail|215px|[[Clint Eastwood]] holding a .44 Magnum in the 1983 film [[Sudden Impact]]]]
 
[[File:S&W Model 29-2.jpg|thumb|right|[[Smith & Wesson Model 29|Smith & Wesson Model 29-2]]]]
[[File:S&W Model 29-2.jpg|thumb|right|[[Smith & Wesson Model 29|Smith & Wesson Model 29-2]]]]
While the .44 Magnum was very popular among shooters for many years after its introduction, it did not come to the attention of the general public until 1971, when [[Clint Eastwood]]'s character [[Harry Callahan (character)|"Dirty" Harry Callahan]] described the .44 Magnum as "the most powerful handgun in the world" in the film ''[[Dirty Harry]]''. While this was not strictly true in 1971 (the more powerful [[.454 Casull]] was announced in 1959, and was available in custom revolvers),<ref name="cotw10" /> it still caused prices of the [[Smith & Wesson Model 29]] to skyrocket; demand far exceeded supply, and guns were selling for triple the normal retail price. This sudden surge in popularity elevated the .44 Magnum to "magical" levels, spawning a mythos, such as the (false) claim that the .44 Magnum could "stop a car at a hundred yardsâput a round right through the engine block"âa claim made by Easy Andy, the gun dealer character in the 1976 film ''[[Taxi Driver (film)|Taxi Driver]]''.<ref name="50years" /><ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.villagevoice.com/film/0614,hoberman,72749,20.html |title=Dirty Harry |author=J. Hoberman |date= March 28, 2006}}</ref> The .44 Magnum continued to be associated with Dirty Harry's character, including the scene with Eastwood's famous line "[[Go ahead, make my day.|Go ahead, make my day]]" in the 1983 film ''[[Sudden Impact]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afi.com/Docs/about/press/2005/quotesannouned.pdf|format=pdf|publisher=[[American Film Institute]]|title=AFI's list of 100 famous movie quotes}}</ref>
While the .44 Magnum was very popular among shooters for many years after its introduction, it did not come to the attention of the general public until 1971, when [[Clint Eastwood]]'s character [[Harry Callahan (character)|"Dirty" Harry Callahan]] described the .44 Magnum as "the most powerful handgun in the world" in the film ''[[Dirty Harry]]''. While this was not strictly true in 1971 (the more powerful [[.454 Casull]] was announced in 1959, and was available in custom revolvers),<ref name="cotw10" /> it still caused prices of the [[Smith & Wesson Model 29]] to skyrocket; demand far exceeded supply, and guns were selling for triple the normal retail price. This sudden surge in popularity elevated the .44 Magnum to "magical" levels, spawning a mythos, such as the (false) claim that the .44 Magnum could "stop a car at a hundred yardsâput a round right through the engine block"âa claim made by Easy Andy, the gun dealer character in the 1976 film ''[[Taxi Driver (film)|Taxi Driver]]''.<ref name="50years" /><ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.villagevoice.com/film/0614,hoberman,72749,20.html |title=Dirty Harry |author=J. Hoberman |date= March 28, 2006}}</ref> The .44 Magnum continued to be associated with Dirty Harry's character, including the scene with Eastwood's famous line "[[Go ahead, make my day.|Go ahead, make my day]]" in the 1983 film ''[[Sudden Impact]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afi.com/Docs/about/press/2005/quotesannouned.pdf|format=pdf|publisher=[[American Film Institute]]|title=AFI's list of 100 famous movie quotes}}</ref>
